Comment: As per [original article](https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2025/04/25/donald-trump-approval-rating-survey/83279671007/) 📰:  - Within the first 100 days of his second administration President Donald Trump has been incredibly busy, implementing major changes from enacting tariffs to targeting diversity initiatives.    But Americans are divided about whether the changes have been good, according to a recent [survey of more than 900 voters conducted by the New York Times and Siena College Research Institute](https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2025/04/25/us/elections/times-siena-poll-crosstabs.html).  Around 54% of participants said they disapprove of the president’s handling of the economy, immigration, foreign trade and the war between Russia and Ukraine.  The poll reported that 56% of participants said Trump has “gone too far” with changes from enacting tariffs, advancing immigration enforcement and cutting the federal work force.  When asked to describe the second Trump Administration, 66% called his term “chaotic” while 42% used “exciting” and 59% said “scary,” according to the poll.  Overall, his approval rating was at 42%.  Trump’s first 100 days: Here’s 100 things that have changed (so far) Americans criticize economy but support immigration  Though confidence in Trump’s ability to manage the economy was a key selling point to many voters in the November election, 76% of participants said they disapprove of how he’s handling it, the survey said.  While 45% said their personal finances are in good shape, 44% expect to be hurt personally by his economic policies.  Around 52% disapproved Trump’s suggestion to U.S. citizen to prison in El Salvador, the Times/Siena poll reported.  Around 47% opposed the administration’s decision to roll back diversity, equity and inclusion programs, and 58% opposed with holding federal funding from certain universities, the survey reported.  Musk has lower approval rating than Trump, poll reports  The world’s richest man, Elon Musk, also received a low approval rating during his stint spearheading the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) alongside Trump.  The Tesla CEO and presidential adviser received an approval rating of just 35%, the survey reported, with skeptics split a consistently across gender, age, racial and educational demographics.  Survey conductors asked participants twice about the DOGE cuts, once mentioning Musk’s name and again without, according to the Times. Responders were more fond of the cuts when they didn’t hear the name “Musk.”  Trump’s 100th day in office is on Wednesday, April 30.

Comment: 25% is actually a bonkers number. There's a thing called "the crazification factor" from the GWB years, which is that about 27% of people will support nearly *anything* you poll on. Comment: I'll take totally weak in a positive direction over what Trump is doing any day.  We're being dismantled as a global power.  Saying "totally weak in a positive direction" is another way of saying "nearly optimal."  That's just the nature of being near the optimal in what can be accomplished.         Would I like a more progressive push?  Hell yes.  Higher taxes on billionaires would be good to help reverse the obscene wealth inequalities we are seeing now.  Universal health care would be good.  And so on.  But politics is the art of the possible, and Biden was doing almost everything possible within the political context of his term.     Will there be a rebound to the Trump crash that ushers in a completely new deal?  Perhaps.  That's what happened after the Great Depression; the political context is likely to be radically different.  If anything good comes from Trump that will be it - a total revulsion and repudiation of the MAGA orthodoxy.

Comment: > to not even vote at all.   I voted for her, so you’re off to a good start with the baseless claims lol  > You wanted a magical, pitch-perfect candidate that can perform miracles, else you wouldn't even reply in disagreement like you are now, considering that nobody said that she isn't perfect and she doesn't deserve criticism.   The person I was replying to literally said the only reason Harris could have lost was “lack of empathy”, “laziness”, and “Black Indian woman”. They claimed every other reason was made up.   Nobody said we should have a magical perfect candidate. I was very specific in my criticism of Harris for running a status quo campaign as a legitimate reason she lost that was in her control.  > deserve his place as President  No one “deserves” to be President lol. The person who makes the best argument for getting people’s votes wins. People who are not good at making that argument should not run for President or accept a VP spot. Harris wasn’t good at that.  > I guess you don't feel the same, considering you think she shouldn't deserve credit for warning us many times what he was gonna do despite people pulling that out as an excuse as to why they didn't vote for her. "She didn't warn us enough that this was gonna happen!!!"   These are three entirely different points.   I don’t feel that people who ask for the most powerful position in the world should see it as something they deserve. They should earn it and part of that means being able to figure out how people are feeling. If they’re demanding change, and you know that but decide to sell them the status quo, you’re to blame when they reject you. If you can’t make a clear vision for people and just assume it’s obvious you’re better, you’re responsible for that assumption.  Anyone can issue a warning. Middle schoolers in 2015 were already calling Trump the next Hitler. Do they deserve credit too? They must be political prodigies to have the same insight as Harris.  My complaint isn’t that Harris didn’t warn us enough. It’s that she raised $2 billion and ran a bad political campaign when it really mattered.  > She literally advocated better wages and for lowering housing costs  Is anyone advocating for worse wages and more expensive housing lol  There's obviously still many problems in our society even while he was president, and there would have been even when she is president,   > but everything takes time. It cannot be repaired or de-escalated immediately.   It took us 1 year to go from introducing Social Security to giving everyone their card. Look at how long the infrastructure bill makes states wait to accept grant money to begin building (hint: it’s longer). Look at how fast other countries are able to build compared to us, from China to Europe. this includes blue areas like CA and NY where Dems run everything. We are uniquely bad right now for no clear reason.   If we as Dems are arguing that government can do good things, we need to have clear answers for why that is since it hasn’t been working so far. This is where Republicans have a clearer answer than Democrats, even if it’s a really bad one.   It’s also a choice to ignore short-term issues in favor of long-term ones. It’s also a choice to decide not to use certain powers to get things done because you value process over outcomes, like Biden honoring an unelected Senate parliamentarian on a minimum wage increase.
Author: Prior_Coyote_4376

Comment: I'm dumbfounded by the reaction of the financial markets. They have access to trade and transport data, they're supposed to be experts, yet they seem to be totally ignoring the facts at hand.   They are acting like everything will suddenly be okay again if Trump waives a wand and eliminates tariffs.  The damage is done.   Shipping logistics are completely screwed for the foreseeable future. Shipments that take weeks (months for logistical components) to make it to market are halted, or shifted to other markets.   I don't think Wall Street realizes how complex the supply change is, or how many components are involved from so many multiple production facilities spread across the globe. Just the shipping confusion will cripple supply lines.  The US tourism market, worth $250 billion a year, is as good as dead. Treasury Bills, the debt that keeps us all going, have been undermined. It is the excess capital of trade deficits that gives nations the liquidity and dollars to purchase T-Bills, and that whole system is in flux.   The US risks being able to service its debt, and that's an issue that should shake markets, but they seem blasé about it. I hope it all holds together, but I don't see how it can.

Comment: > Harris offered a stable economy and measured decisions. I don't think that makes her necessarily wrong.   What makes more sense: people wanted lies and instability, or that you might be biased into thinking Harris’ offer of stability was convincing?  If people don’t feel stable in the status quo, because remember most Americans don’t have $1000 in the bank for emergency payments, but you claim things are stable and intend to keep them as they are, then you’re telling them you’ll keep them unstable. You need to tell them you have clear goals about improving their lives.  For example, run on single payer universal healthcare so people know voting for you means you’ll keep their healthcare stable if they lose their jobs to globalism or automation. Saying you will slightly expand Obamacare is technically helpful but doesn’t address a core fear people have.   Or run an anti-corruption campaign that will go to war with monopolies, price gougers, BS fees, union busting, predatory lenders, wage theft, Wall Street, and billionaires who don’t pay their fair share. Reclaim DEI as a tool to examine worker rights at big corporations and make the marketplace fair. Instead Harris says most companies are good and there’s only a few “bad apples”, and privately dines with the CEOs of corporations with active antitrust suits under Biden  There’s a *lot* Harris could have done differently. Instead, like the 2020 primaries, she didn’t have a clear vision so her good debate and speech moments never led to long term gains.  We as Democrats need to remember that Obama was not a mistake. We can and should have candidates that good at communicating a vision, but we won’t if we think Harris represented the best we could have done.

Author: Owltiger2057

Comment: > That was the MAGA spin.  When fed propaganda lies 24/7/365 half the population "felt" that conditions were getting worse under Biden.    Democrats chose Obama instead of Hillary in 2008 because they wanted an outsider to bring change over Wall Street and globalism. This was pre-MAGA and pre-Tea Party, and a feeling that was strong among Democrats. 13% of Trump voters were Obama voters, many disappointed that Obama didn’t bring the bigger reforms they imagined.  You’re not taking in the bigger picture of the average American who isn’t arguing on political subs, which is that both sides are the same unless they’re doing something new that upsets the status quo establishment.   Yes, MAGA lies and uses propaganda to make Biden and the Dems seem bad. That’s nothing new for the right. But the appetite for change is real and so strong that people preferred an inexperienced black man with the middle name Hussein to a qualified white woman they associated with a previous successful presidency.  People want answers to the big questions: why is the system so rigged, and what are you going to do about it?   The fact that Biden was bringing the economy back to “normal” was not a good selling point when people associated “normal” with the status quo they hated.  > There is no particular virtue in "bold."    I never said there was. My point is that people feel upset and desperate, and not being bold shows that we’re not taking people’s feelings seriously.  > She only had a few weeks to put together policy changes and came up with a few good ones.    The entire point of a VP is to step up and be able to take control of the President’s position at any time if he’s unable to do it. If she can’t do it for a campaign, consider what that implies if Biden had also dropped out of office. There’s almost no other job for a VP to even do except be ready to step up. If Trump left office tomorrow, do you think Vance would be unprepared? These are professional top of the top politicians. We can expect them to have a policy vision at all times.   > half the voting population "felt" that things were getting worse.  They have been. These oligarchs didn’t come out of nowhere. They were building their power and stripping away ours even through Democratic administrations. Education, healthcare, housing, jobs, every area of life has seen increases in expenses and decline in quality for most average people for decades. They’re also facing threats like climate change, AI and automation, offshoring, etc, that neither party is showing urgency at addressing. Trump’s the only one openly saying the system is rigged and should be radically changed to address crises. He’s completely wrong about the reasons it’s rigged and what the crises are, but almost everyone else says the status quo was fine.

Author: Imhappy_hopeurhappy2

Comment: I suspect we agree on a lot of points.  Hillary, in particular, ran on a "Fight for the status quo" platform and lost spectacularly.  We should have had Bernie and the Green New Deal.  But Biden listened.  If you look at many of the positions he quietly put into place you will see many of those bold, progressive ideas.  He has a lot more in common with AOC and Bernie than he does with the neo-liberal democrats as embodied by Pelosi, Schumer, and the Clintons.  Yeah, he voted for the Iraq war, which was foolish, and yeah, he was a little slow on civil rights, but his every-man bona-fides are every bit as genuine as Bernie's and AOC's.    This anti-Democracy coup by the oligarchs has been in motion for a very long time.  It is an echo of the Confederate rebellion, funded and partially organized by our old cold war nemesis and current oligarchy state Russia.  Until this is defeated for good I don't think we can have nice things.
Author: guttanzer
